Both the statements A and B are true
Both the statements A and B are false

questions.text:
Statement A:  Within the pancreatic islets, the S cells exhibit an intímate association with the synthesis and secretion of somatostatin, playing a pivotal role in the regulation of various endocrine and exocrine functions.

 

Statement B: The secretion of glucagon primarily originates from the delta cells, which are a distinct subset within the endocrine pancreas, contributing significantly to the regulation of glucose homeostasis and metabolic responses.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both the statements A and B are false

 

Option D.

 

  • Somatostatin will be secreted from the delta cells (D cells) of the islets of Langerhans of the endocrine pancreas
  • Glucagon is a polypeptide hormone secreted from the alpha cells (A cells) of the pancreatic islets (not gamma cells)
  • Insulin is secreted from the beta cells (B cells) of the islets of Langerhans of
    the b

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Somatostatin secretion occurs primarily from the delta cells, not S cells, within the pancreatic islets, while glucagon is chiefly produced by alpha cells, not gamma cells, under scoring the correct celular origins of these key pancreatic hormones involved in regulating endocrine function and glucose homeostasis.

 

Ref: Ganong’ s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 444

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with fatigue and weakness. Lab results show low hemoglobin levels and microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells. Further testing indicates a deficiency in iron metabolism and homeostasis. Which storage form of iron is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ferritin

 

Option C. Correct. Ferritin is the primary storage form of iron within cells, crucial in iron metabolism.

 

The iron absorbed inside the enterocytes will be stored as ferritin (intracellular storage protein of iron)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A - Ferroportin: A protein that transports iron from inside cells to the outside; not a storage form.

 

Option B - Hepcidin: A regulatory hormone that controls iron absorption and release but is not a storage form.

 

Option D - Transferrin: A transport protein in blood; carries iron but is not a storage form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the role of ferritin as the primary storage form of iron in the body, essential in the context of diagnosing and managing iron deficiency anemia.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 484

choices.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
The assertion statement is correct, but the reason statement is incorrect
Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.text:
Assertion: The lower esophageal sphincter will be tonically active

 

Reason: The sympathetic stimulation will result in the contraction of the intrinsic sphincter

 

Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The assertion statement is correct, but the reason statement is incorrect

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the Gastro-Esophageal Junction, the musculature called the Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES) will be tonically active
  • This tonic activity of the sphincter between the successive meals will prevent the reflux of the gastric contents (regurgitation) back into the esophagus
  • During swallowing, the sphincter will be relaxed
  • The release of acetylcholine from the vagal nerve endings (parasympathetic activity) will cause the intrinsic sphincter (esophageal smooth muscle) to go for contraction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that while the Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES) is tonically active to prevent reflux, its contraction is primarily mediated by myogenic mechanisms and intrinsic neural plexuses, not sympathetic stimulation.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 498

questions.text: Match the lipases and associated factors with their primary site of activation and function in the gastrointestinal tract:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1-A (Lingual lipase - Mouth): Begins fat digestion.
  • 2-B (Gastric lipase - Stomach): Continues fat digestion in the acidic environment.
  • 3-C (Pancreatic lipase - Small intestine): Key enzyme for the final stages of fat digestion.
  • 4-D (Colipase - Small intestine): Essential co-factor for pancreatic lipase, enhancing its function.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the specific roles and sites of activation for different lipases and colipase in the gastrointestinal tract, crucial for the efficient digestion of dietary fats.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 474, 75

questions.text:
Which of the following are secreted from the parietal cells of the stomach?

 

  1. Mucous
  2. Hydrochloric acid
  3. Gastrin
  4. Intrinsic factor
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4 (Hydrochloric Acid and Intrinsic Factor)

 

Option B. Correct. Parietal cells in the stomach are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid, essential for digestion, and intrinsic factor, vital for vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Different Cells and their Secretions are the following:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While parietal cells secrete hydrochloric acid, which is crucial for stomach acidity and digestion, they also secrete another important component.

 

Option C. Gastrin is not secreted by parietal cells; it is secreted by G cells in the stomach lining.

 

Option D. Mucous and gastrin are not secreted by parietal cells. Mucous is secreted by mucous cells, and gastrin by G cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the specific roles of parietal cells in the stomach, particularly their secretion of hydrochloric acid for digestion and intrinsic factor for vitamin B12 absorption, distinguishing their functions from those of other stomach cell types.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no: 427

questions.text: A 16-month-old male child was admitted in the pediatric ward with a history of loose stools for the past 2 weeks and poor weight gain since birth. On detailed evaluation, the child was diagnosed to have cystic fibrosis. Which of the following channels in the gastrointestinal tract are expected to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chloride Channels

 

Option D: Correct. Cystic fibrosis is characterized by a genetic defect affecting the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene, which encodes a protein that functions as a chloride channel. This affects various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While sodium channels are important in fluid and electrolyte balance, cystic fibrosis primarily affects chloride channels, not sodium channels.

 

Option B: Calcium channels are crucial in various cellular processes, but they are not the primary channels affected in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C: Potassium channels help regulate cellular excitability and fluid balance. However, in cystic fibrosis, the defect is in chloride channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that cystic fibrosis primarily affects chloride channels due to a defect in the CFTR gene, leading to symptoms like malabsorption and chronic lung disease.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 466

choices.text: Luteinizing Hormone (LH)
Insulin
Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH)
Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH)

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the mechanisms of action of various hormones for an upcoming exam. She is focusing on the types of receptors that different hormones bind to. Which of the following hormones primarily acts through a tyrosine kinase receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin

 

Option B. Insulin binds to and activates tyrosine kinase receptors, which initiate a cascade of cellular actions crucial for glucose uptake and metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone (LH) operates through a G protein-coupled receptor. It plays a critical role in the regulation of the reproductive system.

 

Option C. Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH) acts through a G protein-coupled receptor, stimulating the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones.

 

Option D. Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH), which triggers the release of TSH, also acts via G protein-coupled receptors, not through tyrosine kinase receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that insulin acts through a tyrosine kinase receptor, which is distinct from the G protein-coupled receptors used by many other hormones such as LH, TSH, and TRH.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page Number: 933.

choices.text: Decreased Proliferation of Epithelial Cells
Synthesis of Short Chain Fatty Acid

questions.text: A nutritionist is discussing the multifaceted roles of gut flora with a group of patients interested in gut health. She presents various functions of the gut microbiota and asks the group to identify which is not a typical function of gut flora. Which of the following is NOT a function of gut flora?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased Proliferation of Epithelial Cells

 

Option C. This is not a typical function of gut flora. In fact, a healthy gut microbiota often supports the proliferation and maintenance of healthy epithelial cells in the gastrointestinal tract. A disrupted or unhealthy microbiome may contribute to decreased cell proliferation or even damage, but it is not a normal function.

 

Functions of colonic bacteria:

 

  • Fermentation of nondigestible dietary residue and endogenous mucus
  • Production Short-Chain Fatty Acids (SCFA) and vitamin K
  • Absorption of ions
  • Increase in epithelial cell proliferation (tropic effect of SCFA) and differentiation.
  • Development and homoeostasis of the immune system.
  • Protection against pathogens (the barrier effect).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gut flora can ferment mucin, a component of the mucus in the gastrointestinal tract. This process is part of the normal activity of certain gut bacteria and helps in maintaining the balance of the gut microbiome.

 

Option B. The gut flora, particularly certain types of bacteria, are known for synthesizing vitamin K, which is crucial for blood clotting and bone health. This synthesis is a well-recognized function of the gut microbiota.

 

Option D. Gut bacteria are responsible for the synthesis of Short-Chain Fatty Acids (SCFAs) through the fermentation of dietary fibers. SCFAs are important for colon health and provide energy to colonocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective of this question is to understand the beneficial functions of gut flora, including fermentation of mucin, production of vitamins like vitamin K, and synthesis of short-chain fatty acids, and to recognize that decreased proliferation of epithelial cells is not a typical function of a healthy gut microbiota.

 

Ref- Digestive Processes of the Large Intestine" section in Medicine Libre-Texts; Lancet 2003; 361:512-19
